body: @ShirinNajdi why is your `--server`  like this `172.17.0.2/16:9000` ? It needs to be a valid single IP address (and port), no?

@sanjaypujare I got this address running the following code:

`docker network inspect bridge | grep IPv4Address`

and got the following result:

`"IPv4Address": "172.17.0.2/16"`
"172.17.0.2/16" is not a valid IPv4 address. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv4#Address_representations
@ShirinNajdi Closing for now. If you have further problems, feel free to reopen.
@ShirinNajdi Have you found the solution for this?

> @ShirinNajdi Have you found the solution for this?

No, still trying to find a solution!

@ShirinNajdi Can you please provide more details about your setup? What is the content of your `client.py` file? Can you link us to the `tensorflow-serving` docker image you mentioned above?

As @sanjaypujare suggested, it looks like an invalid IP. Have you tried dropping the `/16` from the end? i.e.
```
python client.py --server=172.17.0.2:9000 --image=./test_images/image2.jpg
```

@gnossen I have found some thing strange that the server client works fine without casino any connect vpn connection but will not work when I establish the vpn connection. Besides the server address is localhost:9000.
@gnossen You may find some useful environment information here #18386

> @ShirinNajdi Can you please provide more details about your setup? What is the content of your `client.py` file? Can you link us to the `tensorflow-serving` docker image you mentioned above?
> 
> As @sanjaypujare suggested, it looks like an invalid IP. Have you tried dropping the `/16` from the end? i.e.
> 
> ```
> python client.py --server=172.17.0.2:9000 --image=./test_images/image2.jpg
> ```

I already tried without /16. It didn't work.

I am using "tensorflow-serving-devel-cpu" 

Here is my client.py code:


`

    
    from argparse import ArgumentParser
    import time
    # Communication to TensorFlow server via gRPC
    from grpc.beta import implementations
    import tensorflow as tf
    
    # TensorFlow serving stuff to send messages
    from tensorflow_serving.apis import predict_pb2
    from tensorflow_serving.apis import prediction_service_pb2
    from tensorflow.contrib.util import make_tensor_proto
    
    from tensorflow.contrib.util import make_tensor_proto
    
    from os import listdir
    from os.path import isfile, join
    
    
    def parse_args():
        parser = ArgumentParser(description='Request a TensorFlow server for a prediction on the image')
        parser.add_argument('-s', '--server',
                            dest='server',
                            default='172.17.0.2:9000',
                            help='prediction service host:port')
        parser.add_argument("-i", "--image",
                            dest="image",
                            default='',
                            help="path to image in JPEG format", )
        parser.add_argument('-p', '--image_path',
                            dest='image_path',
                            default='',
                            help='path to images folder', )
        parser.add_argument('-b', '--batch_mode',
                            dest='batch_mode',
                            default='true',
                            help='send image as batch or one-by-one')
        args = parser.parse_args()
    
        host, port = args.server.split(':')
    
        return host, port, args.image, args.image_path, args.batch_mode == 'true'
    
    
    def main():
        # parse command line arguments
        host, port, image, image_path, batch_mode = parse_args()
    
        channel = implementations.insecure_channel(host, int(port))
        stub = prediction_service_pb2.beta_create_PredictionService_stub(channel)
    
        imagedata = []
        if len(image_path) > 0:
            filenames = [(image_path + '/' + f) for f in listdir(image_path) if isfile(join(image_path, f))]
            for filename in filenames:
                with open(filename, 'rb') as f:
                    data = f.read()
                    imagedata.append(data)
        else:
            with open(image, 'rb') as f:
                data = f.read()
                imagedata.append(data)
    
        start = time.time()
    
        if batch_mode:
            print('In batch mode')
            request = predict_pb2.PredictRequest()
            print('predict_pb2.PredictRequest')
            request.model_spec.name = 'fruit_detect'  # Change this to your model name
            print('request.model_spec.name')
            request.model_spec.signature_name = 'predict_images'
            print('request.model_spec.signature_name')
    
            request.inputs['images'].CopyFrom(make_tensor_proto(imagedata, shape=[len(imagedata)]))
            print('request.inputs')
            result = stub.Predict(request, 120.0)
            print('result')
            print(result)
        else:
            print('In one-by-one mode')
            for data in imagedata:
                request = predict_pb2.PredictRequest()
                request.model_spec.name = 'fruit_detect'  # Change this to your model name
                request.model_spec.signature_name = 'predict_images'
    
                request.inputs['images'].CopyFrom(make_tensor_proto(data, shape=[1]))
    
                result = stub.Predict(request, 60.0)  # 60 secs timeout
                print(result)
    
        end = time.time()
        time_diff = end - start
        print('time elapased: {}'.format(time_diff))
    
    
    if __name__ == '__main__':
        main()
`

@ShirinNajdi Your client-side code looks okay. You'll definitely want to go without the bit length suffix (the `/16`). I'm still not 100% sure which docker image you're using on the server side, though. Is it [this one?](https://hub.docker.com/r/qingcloud/tensorflow-serving-devel-cpu).

> @ShirinNajdi Your client-side code looks okay. You'll definitely want to go without the bit length suffix (the `/16`). I'm still not 100% sure which docker image you're using on the server side, though. Is it [this one?](https://hub.docker.com/r/qingcloud/tensorflow-serving-devel-cpu).

This is the [link](https://hub.docker.com/r/tensorflow/serving) for the docker image that I use. I chose the latest-devel version.

I even tried without /16, and still didn't work!

@ShirinNajdi: Found this issue while debugging a different problem with a different set of libraries that also used gRPC (firebase-admin). I found that uninstalling the python library grpcio-1.19.0 and installing grpcio-1.18 solved my issue.

`$ pip3 install grpcio==1.18
Collecting grpcio==1.18
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/cd/9d/e707b8a041171ca436c066a544f59a090a700c6742f323a074fc5989297f/grpcio-1.18.0-cp37-cp37m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl (1.8MB)
    100% |████████████████████████████████| 1.8MB 13.8MB/s 
Requirement already satisfied: six>=1.5.2 in /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages (from grpcio==1.18) (1.12.0)
Installing collected packages: grpcio
Successfully installed grpcio-1.18.0`

using:
`macOS 10.14.3 (18D109)`
`python 3.7.3`

Hope it helps!

A "Name resolution error" when targeting an IP literal like `172.17.0.2` is very odd. Can I suggest running under environment variables:
`GRPC_VERBOSITY=DEBUG`
`GRPC_TRACE=api,client_channel_routing,cares_resolver`

and posting the output here? That could give some insights for the "Name resolution error".

Hi @apolcyn 
I encountered a similar error after updating my native C++ client from gRPC v1.15.0 to v1.19.1.
The scenario - the **Windows** client tries to resolve `myserver`, while the actual DNS record is `myserver.local` (the `local` DNS suffix is set by DHCP on the relevant network interface).
In Wireshark I can see the client tries to resolve `myserver` explicitly, and gets the `NXDOMAIN` error back. (Of course, ping-ing `myserver` is resolved by Windows to `myserver.local` successfully).

It looks like c-ares tries to resolve the host without the DNS suffix, and understandably the DNS returns the `NXDOMAIN` error.
What was changed here since v1.15.0 that worked well in resolving the host without an explicit suffix?
This regression is a deal-breaker for us. Are we doing something wrong here? Are there any new build flags, or new channel configuration properties, that we should set?

Digging a bit deeper, it looks like c-ares tries to resolve the host-without-suffix name, receives 103 bytes back and fails (with `Cancelled` error message) - and then decides to shut the channel down:
```log
D0408 10:06:40.177000000 16776 grpc_ares_ev_driver.cc:212] (c-ares resolver) request:0000019796C84B20 ev_driver=0000019796A5FBC0 on_timeout_locked. driver->shutting_down=1. err="Cancelled"
...
D0408 10:06:40.177000000 16776 dns_resolver_ares.cc:356] (c-ares resolver) resolver:0000019796C73DC0 dns resolution failed: {"created":"@1554707200.177000000","description":"C-ares status is not ARES_SUCCESS: Domain name not found","file":"C:\Projects\git\grpc\src\core\ext\filters\client_channel\resolver\dns\c_ares\grpc_ares_wrapper.cc","file_line":241,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1554707200.177000000","description":"C-ares status is not ARES_SUCCESS: Domain name not found","file":"C:\Projects\git\grpc\src\core\ext\filters\client_channel\resolver\dns\c_ares\grpc_ares_wrapper.cc","file_line":241}]}
D0408 10:06:40.177000000 16776 dns_resolver_ares.cc:360] (c-ares resolver) resolver:0000019796C73DC0 dns resolution failed (will retry): {"created":"@1554707200.177000000","description":"C-ares status is not ARES_SUCCESS: Domain name not found","file":"C:\Projects\git\grpc\src\core\ext\filters\client_channel\resolver\dns\c_ares\grpc_ares_wrapper.cc","file_line":241,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1554707200.177000000","description":"C-ares status is not ARES_SUCCESS: Domain name not found","file":"C:\Projects\git\grpc\src\core\ext\filters\client_channel\resolver\dns\c_ares\grpc_ares_wrapper.cc","file_line":241}]}
D0408 10:06:40.177000000 16776 dns_resolver_ares.cc:370] (c-ares resolver) resolver:0000019796C73DC0 retrying in 1000 milliseconds
```
Although `retrying in 1000 milliseconds` is logged, there was no retry logic as far as I can see and the channel shuts down completely.

> @ShirinNajdi: Found this issue while debugging a different problem with a different set of libraries that also used gRPC (firebase-admin). I found that uninstalling the python library grpcio-1.19.0 and installing grpcio-1.18 solved my issue.
> 
> `$ pip3 install grpcio==1.18 Collecting grpcio==1.18 Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/cd/9d/e707b8a041171ca436c066a544f59a090a700c6742f323a074fc5989297f/grpcio-1.18.0-cp37-cp37m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl (1.8MB) 100% |████████████████████████████████| 1.8MB 13.8MB/s Requirement already satisfied: six>=1.5.2 in /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages (from grpcio==1.18) (1.12.0) Installing collected packages: grpcio Successfully installed grpcio-1.18.0`
> 
> using:
> `macOS 10.14.3 (18D109)`
> `python 3.7.3`
> 
> Hope it helps!

Thanks for the advice.

After installing grpcio-1.18.0, and removing /16 form address, the error is different like as follows:

`debug_error_string = "{"created":"@1554725602.252122000","description":"Failed to create subchannel","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/client_channel.cc","file_line":2261,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1554725602.252114000","description":"Pick Cancelled","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/pick_first/pick_first.cc","file_line":245,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1554725602.251810000","description":"Connect Failed","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/subchannel.cc","file_line":867,"grpc_status":14,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1554725602.251761000","description":"Failed to connect to remote host: FD shutdown","file":"src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_poll_posix.cc","file_line":532,"grpc_status":14,"os_error":"Timeout occurred","referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1554725602.251699000","description":"connect() timed out","file":"src/core/lib/iomgr/tcp_client_posix.cc","file_line":119}],"target_address":"ipv4:172.17.0.2:9000"}]}]}]}"`

> A "Name resolution error" when targeting an IP literal like `172.17.0.2` is very odd. Can I suggest running under environment variables:
> `GRPC_VERBOSITY=DEBUG`
> `GRPC_TRACE=api,client_channel_routing,cares_resolver`
> 
> and posting the output here? That could give some insights for the "Name resolution error".

@ShirinNajdi thanks - from the log you just posted though, I think that you're using the 1.18 release (or you're using the 1.19 release and setting `GRPC_DNS_RESOLVER=native` env var setting). As such, unfortunately this doesn't give the info I'm looking for. What would be really interesting is if you could run your code essentially how I assume it was at the status of [this earlier comment](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/18290#issuecomment-474766747) - i.e. with the 1.19 release, at default settings, but still using the ip address that doesn't end in /16. Can you please run your code as such, under: ``` GRPC_VERBOSITY=DEBUG GRPC_TRACE=api,client_channel_routing,cares_resolver ``` thanks

Finally I was able to solve the issue using the following link:

[https://medium.com/@smsrikanthreddy/hi-vitaly-8aa7805807b0](url)

basically I run the following lines:

`docker run --name=tf_container -it -p 9000:9000 $USER/tensorflow-serving-devel-cpu` 

`python client.py --server=localhost:9000 --image=./test_images/image2.jpg`

Thanks for all of the feedback
